tossups.answer: Germany [or German Empire; or Second Reich] <Cheyne>

answers: Jordan [or Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan; or Al-Mamlakah Al-Urdunniyah Al-Hashimiyah] <Shimizu>
parts: Give this four-letter Arabic and Hebrew word that can either refer to a valley or a dried-up riverbed.
Wadi Qumran (koom-RAHN), near the Jordan River, is where this collection of nearly a thousand manuscripts of Jewish scriptures was found in 1947. It is named after an incredibly salty body of water.

Wadi Rum (room), named for the presence of Byzantine monks in the area, is in the south of this country. The Nabataeans, whose capital was a rock-cut city in this country, also left markings at Wadi Rum.

answers: Skeptic [do not accept any other answers] <Cheyne>
parts: Name this oldest continuously published monthly magazine in the US. It is similar to but should not be confused with Popular Science.
The front page of the first issue of Scientific American discussed this mode of transportation. The B&O company ran this mode of transportation.
The author of Why People Believe Weird Things, Michael Shermer, contributes a regular column to Scientific American with this name, which is also the name of the magazine he himself edits.

answers: "The Lady with the Dog" [or "The Lady with the Lap Dog"; or "Dama s sobachkoy"; accept any answer involving a lady and dog]
parts: Name this story about the bank worker Dmitri, who meets Anna and falls in love with her while both are vacationing in Yalta.
This Russian author of the play The Cherry Orchard wrote the story "The Lady with the Dog."
This Chekhov story is about the scholar Kovrin, who sees visions of the mysterious title figure. Kovrin believes he has the power to use his genius to save mankind.

answers: Jonestown [or the People's Temple Agricultural Project; prompt on the People's Temple]
parts: Name this location where over 900 people died in 1978, mostly as a result of being forced to drink cyanide in a "revolutionary suicide" plan.
Jonestown was formed by the religious group known as the People's Temple, which during the 1970s was based in this state. Its leader, Jim Jones, enjoyed good relations with Governor Jerry Brown.
This California Congressman was killed hours before the mass suicides after he had traveled to Jonestown to investigate reports of people being held against their will.

answers: Michelangelo [or Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni; that contemporary is Leonardo da Vinci]
covering nude figures [or covering genitals; or painting fig leaves or clothing over the figures; prompt on censorship] <Shimizu>
parts: Name this artist who served under the apprenticeship of Domenico Ghirlandaio. He was commissioned to paint a fresco of The Battle of Cascina (KAH-shee-nah) while a contemporary painted The Battle of Anghiari, although both paintings are now lost.
Despite a popular legend, Michelangelo did not lie down while painting the ceiling of this Vatican building, which he decorated with nine Biblical scenes, including The Creation of Adam.

Michelangelo's contemporary, Daniele da Volterra, earned the nickname "Il Braghettone" (bra-gay-TOH-nay) for modifying the Sistine Chapel's Last Judgment fresco in this manner in response to the Council of Trent. A description is acceptable.
Name these column-like or oval-shaped objects used in Hinduism as a representation of the god considered the "destroyer."
The linga represents this god in Hinduism. He forms a trinity with Brahma and Vishnu.

This disciple of Ramakrishna was adamant that the linga was not a phallic symbol. He gave an 1893 speech in Chicago introducing Hinduism at the Parliament of the World's Religions and helped revive the religion in India.

answers: trinucleotide repeat disorders [or TNR expansion disorders; prompt on polyglutamine tract or polyQ tract expansion disorders]
mitochondrial DNA [or mtDNA; or mDNA; prompt on DNA]
transfer RNA [or tRNA; prompt on RNA] <Fulgenzi>
parts: Name these disorders that arise from dynamic mutations in genes like frataxin and DM1 and commonly exhibit the phenomenon of anticipation.
Other maternally-inherited disorders arise from defects in this nucleic acid specific to a certain organelle. It encodes just 37 genes.

Maternally-inherited diabetes and deafness develop from a mutation in the mtDNA that encodes one of these molecules, which comprise the bulk of mtDNA genes. These molecules become "charged" by a namesake amino-acyl synthetase.
Name these objects that dampen or modify the sound that pianos can produce. Modern pianos usually include three of these objects, which are called "soft," "sostenuto," and "sustain."
During the 1880s, this company began to dominate the American piano market. Today, almost all major concert pianists perform using this company's pianos.
G. Henle Verlag (jee HAIN-luh fur-LOCK) specializes in publishing these editions of sheet music, which attempt to reproduce the composer's original intentions without any later additions.

answers: Bandung (bon-DOONG) Conference [prompt on Asian-African or Afro-Asian Conference]
parts: Name this 1955 meeting in Indonesia mostly attended by newly independent Asian and African states. It helped lay the groundwork for future meetings that would establish the Non-Aligned Movement.

Shortly before arriving at the conference, this diplomat was almost killed when the aircraft Kashmir Princess was damaged by a bomb explosion. John Foster Dulles refused to shake this man's hand at the 1954 Geneva Conference.
The eventual Non-Aligned Movement featured such leaders as Gamal Abdel Nasser, the second president of this Arabic country within Africa.

answers: "Bright Star" [or "Bright star, would I were stedfast as thou art"]
parts: Name this sonnet by Keats whose speaker wishes to be as steadfast as the title object in his devotion, yet would not wish for its solitude and seclusion.

John Keats presented Fanny Brawne with the final version of "Bright Star" in 1819. Also in that year, Keats wrote five of his most acclaimed odes and this poem, which vividly describes a "season of mists and mellow fruitfulness."
The speaker states that "My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains my sense, as though of hemlock I had drunk" at the start of this Keats ode addressed to a bird.

answers: abdication of Christina [accept synonyms like leaving the throne in place of "abdication"; prompt on queen in place of "Christina"]
parts: Name this event that affected a woman known as the "Minerva of the North," who had decided to convert to Catholicism and refused to marry.

Christina's abdication meant that the throne passed to Charles X Gustav of the House of Palatinate-Zweibrücken (ts-VYE-brook-in). Christina and her father, Gustavus Adolphus, were members of this royal house.
Christina ruled this Scandinavian country.

answers: Ford Madox Ford [or Ford Hermann Hueffer; or Ford Madox Hueffer]
parts: This writer's tetralogy Parade's End relates the story of Christopher Tietjens (TEE-chins), whose experiences in the war include watching his friend's leg get blown off by a mortar shell. Another of his novels is about Edward Ashburnham.
Septimus Smith suffers from posttraumatic stress disorder and commits suicide by jumping from a window in this female author's novel Mrs. Dalloway.

World War I veteran Tom Birkin struggles with his spiritual views while restoring a church in this eccentric writer's Booker Prize-nominated book A Month in the Country. He also founded the Quince Tree Press publishing company.

answers: September 11 attacks [or 9/11; or 2001 World Trade Center attacks] <Sy>
parts: Name this 2010 novel whose title state of being is arguably achieved by its character Patty Berglund when she is kicked out of her Georgetown house by her husband, Walter.
Freedom is a novel by this contemporary author who wrote about the Lambert family in The Corrections.

While attending the University of Virginia, Patty Berglund's son Joey reconsiders his worldview after this event. In his poem "Somebody Blew Up America," Amiri Baraka asks why "4000 Israeli workers" stayed home during this event.

answers: human capital [do not accept or prompt on "capital"] <Droge>
parts: Name this phenomenon that is also the subject of Walt Rostow's take-off model. It is defined as the expansion of the value of an economy over time.
This exogenous growth model was developed in the 1950s. It begins by constructing a Cobb–Douglas production function for an economy whose inputs are labor and capital.

The Mankiw (MAN-kyoo)–Romer–Weil adjustment to the Solow model adds this element, symbolized H, to the aggregate production function. Much like the other inputs, it is calculated as a function of time.

answers: existential risks [prompt on human extinction or nuclear war or logically equivalent answers implying apocalyptic scenarios]
artificial intelligence [or AI; accept equivalents like computers, machines, robots, computer programs, etc.]
parts: Bostrom introduced the concept of these things in a namesake paper, where he described them as "global, terminal" risks. He argued that moral actions ought to maximize the probability that these risks do not happen.
Bostrom argues that the development of a superintelligent one of these could be an existential risk. Alan Turing names a "test" for determining whether these things are equivalent to humans.

Bostrom's trilemma argues that unless most human civilizations fail to reach a post-human level, it is likely that our universe is one of these things. Arguments that the universe is one of these things include physical evidence that the universe has a minimum resolution, or that time is divided into discrete blocks.

answers: The Nutcracker [or Shchelkunchik, Balet-feyeriya; or Casse-Noisette, ballet-féerie] <Gupta>
parts: Name this two-act 1962 ballet set to the music of a classical composition that is itself based on a literary work. This ballet incorporates many pieces by the same composer of that piece, such as String Symphony No. 9 in C minor and The First Walpurgis Night.
A Midsummer Night's Dream was the first complete full-length ballet by this co-founder of the New York City Ballet, a Georgian émigré from the Soviet Union.

A Midsummer Night's Dream shares the same broad "Act I story, Act II dancing" format as Balanchine's staging of this other ballet, in which he played the mime role of Drosselmeyer. In this ballet with music by Tchaikovsky, the title toy becomes human after defeating the Mouse King.

answers: one [or 1; or one-plus; or plus-one; or 1+; or +1] <Pendyala>
parts: Name this reaction in which diazoketones rearrange to form ketenes, which can undergo subsequent 2-plus-2 cycloaddition or hydration to form carboxylic acids.
The Wolff rearrangement can be catalyzed by salts of this element, as can the Hofmann elimination. Tollens' reagent is formed by adding ammonia to the oxide of this transition metal.
This is the oxidation state at which silver is most stable. This is also the number of electrons that must be added to a halogen atom to form an ion with a complete octet.
Name this 1974 coup triggered by the playing of "E Depois do Adeus" (ee duh-POISH doo ah-DAY-oosh), an entry in the recent Eurovision song contest.
The Carnation Revolution overthrew the Estado Novo (ee-STAH-doo NOH-voo) in this European country that owned such colonies as Angola and Mozambique.
In December 1961, Portugal lost this colonial possession after a two-day engagement that featured an attack on the warship Alfonso de Albuquerque.
Name this lover of Cephalus. Cephalus accidentally killed this daughter of Erechtheus and sister of Oreithyia when she trailed him on a hunt to see if he was cheating on her.
In some stories, Cephalus is briefly abducted by Eos to be her lover like this son of Laomedon who aged into a cicada after Eos forget to ask Zeus to give him eternal youth.
Procris gave Cephalus a magic javelin that flies back to him after use and an inescapable one of these animals named Laelaps. These animals killed Actaeon after Artemis turned him into a stag.
Name this type of process that increases the entropy of the universe. Heat transfer through a finite temperature difference and processes involving friction are this type of process.
The fact that irreversible processes increase entropy is explained by this statement. Maxwell's demon could hypothetically violate this statement.

An example of an irreversible process is the Joule expansion, in which a gas is allowed to expand into an initially evacuated container. If the gas is a monatomic ideal gas, then the entropy change can be determined using this equation. It is only valid when the volume is much greater than the product of the particle number and the cube of the thermal wavelength.

answers: Gus [or his partner; or fellow killer; accept obvious equivalents] <Cheyne>
parts: What object does Stanley receive as a gift from Lulu in a 1957 play? He closes the first act by using this object, almost menacingly in the direction of Meg, and McCann puts it on the floor to be stepped on during the game.
The toy drum is a crucial prop in the play The Birthday Party by this English author of The Homecoming and The Dumb Waiter.
At the end of The Dumb Waiter, Ben, the hit man, is surprised to discover that his target is apparently this man. Name or description is acceptable.
